item.title: Could autonomous ships make the open seas safer?
item.description:
Could autonomous ships make the open seas safer?

Earlier this month, the El Faro cargo ship mysteriously disappeared as it approached the Bahamas, where it collided with the 125-mph winds and 50-foot seas of Hurricane Joaquin. The US Coast Guard believes the ship sank after taking on water and seeing its engines fail, though a clearer picture likely won't emerge until authorities recover its voyage recorder.

item.title: Why ancient Rome matters to the modern world
item.description:
Why ancient Rome matters to the modern world

By the late fourth century CE the river Danube had become Rome's Calais. What we often call the "invasions" into the Roman empire of barbarian hordes (or "swarms", perhaps) could equally well be described as mass movements of economic migrants or political refugees from northern Europe.

item.title: Basics of Space Flight: Orbital Mechanics
item.description:
Basics of Space Flight: Orbital Mechanics

Orbital mechanics, also called flight mechanics, is the study of the motions of artificial satellites and space vehicles moving under the influence of forces such as gravity, atmospheric drag, thrust, etc. Orbital mechanics is a modern offshoot of celestial mechanics which is the study of the motions of natural celestial bodies such as the moon and planets.

item.title: I just turned a Windows phone into a PC
item.description:
I just turned a Windows phone into a PC

Microsoft unveiled its first Windows 10 Mobile devices today: the Lumia 950 and Lumia 950 XL. Both include an impressive new feature: Continuum. It allows Windows 10 Mobile devices (that include hardware support) to transform into a PC-like interface.

item.title: Why The Internet Needs IPFS Before It's Too Late
item.description:
Why The Internet Needs IPFS Before It's Too Late

IPFS isn't exactly a well-known technology yet, even among many in the Valley, but it's quickly spreading by word of mouth among folks in the open-source community. Many are excited by its potential to greatly improve file transfer and streaming speeds across the Internet. From my personal perspective, however, it's actually much more important than that.

item.title: Brand Loyalty Is for Suckers
item.description:
Brand Loyalty Is for Suckers

Every year, when a new tech product is announced, the world divides into two kinds of people: people who line up to buy the New Shiny Thing, and people who rant about how New Shiny Thing sucks. Both of those groups of people are chumps.
